In another letter addressed to DGP R P Thakur, Naidu said a number of complaints were received from the contesting candidates and polling agents about violent incidents. He alleged YSRC leaders obstructed the polling process and resorted to violence in Kadapa, Anantapur, Kurnool and Nellore districts. In certain cases, they damaged the polling material like EVMs and threatened the polling personnel to allow them to rig the votes, he said. Naidu further added that controlling law and order situation is immediate necessity and requested the DGP to instruct all district superintendents of police to take stringent measures to bring the culprits to the book. Naidu also submitted a list of places where violent incidents were reported across the state. Clashes between TDP and YSRCP workers first erupted in Palnadu region of Guntur district and parts of Rayalaseema, amid news that the YSRCP candidate was kidnapped in Chittoor district. YSRCP candidate MS Babu in Puthalapattu was kidnapped allegedly by TDP workers. In Narasaraopet assembly segment, YSRCP MLA and candidate G Srinivasa Reddy also received injuries. Two contesting candidates in Guntur and Anantapur districts damaged the electronic voting machines (EVMs) by hurling them on the ground. Incidents of stone-pelting and attack by lathis were reported from Kurnool district also. Soon after polling began at 7 am, workers from both parties engaged in heated argument and clashed with each other. Police resorted to mild lathicharge at a few places to disperse the mob. Both TDP and YSRCP traded charges of rigging and violation of model code of conduct as complaints and counter complaints were lodged with the EC. Assembly Speaker and Sattenapalle candidate K Sivaprasada Rao was among the candidates injured in attacks by rivals. Rao entered a polling station and shut it from inside, before police intervened and brought him out. Tourism minister B Akhila Priya’s husband Bhargav and sister Mounika were injured in Allagadda in Kurnool district. In Vijayawada, TDP leader and MLC Buddha Venkanna was taken into custody after he staged a dharna over malfunction of EVMs.

title: Woman banker files domestic violence complaint
og_title: Woman banker files domestic violence complaint
content: AHMEDABAD: A 35-year-old woman, resident of Satellite and deputy manager in a nationalized bank, has filed a complaint of domestic violence against her husband, who also works with a private bank, for torturing her constantly since they got married in January 2014. The complainant, a native of Kolkata in West Bengal, stated that she got married on January 22, 2014 according to social customs. After their marriage, she stayed in Satellite area of the city with her parents and her husband went to Mumbai where he was working at that time. “My father was a heart patient and my mother was visually impaired so I took the responsibility to take care of them. My husband, who was aware of my parents’ condition before marriage, did not like that. After he shifted to Ahmedabad in December 2014, he began behaving badly and inhumanly with my parents and he even dictated how and where they should sleep and sit in my house,” stated the complainant in her FIR with Satellite police filed on Monday. The complainant’s husband used to taunt her parents for not giving enough dowry to her and even tortured her whenever she raised her voice against his taunts. Due to his harassment, the woman’s parents left their house and shifted to an old age home. However, the man was not content with that as he stopped the complainant from taling to her parents whenever she wanted to ask about their well-being on phone. On March 3, when her parents came to see their grandson at the complainant’s place, the accused thrashed the elderly couple, stated the FIR. After this, she filed complaint with Satellite police against him under charges of assault and domestic violence. Installed CCTV to monitor his wife The complainant alleged that her husband had installed CCTV in their house to monitor her from his cellphone as he doubted her character. He even used to check her vehicle to learn ow many kilometres she drove to ensure that she did not drive some extra miles to meet someone else. The man also checked her cellphone often to make sure that she was not talking to any other man, stated the FIR. Man tries to slash wife A 30-year-old woman from Mumbai, married to a Ghatlodia resident, filed a complaint with police on Tuesday stating that her husband had tried to slash her face with a blade as she did not bring Rs 12 lakh from her brother as demanded by him and his parents. The complainant, who hails from Thane West near Mumbai, stated that she got married to her elder brother’s friend on December 10, 2017. She alleged that her husband and in-laws used to taunt her for not bringing dowry and she was forced to give Rs 20,000 per month to her husband. She had in July 2018 come to know that her husband had an extra-marital affair with some woman but when she raised this issue, she was thrashed by her husband. Recently, she was asked to bring Rs 12 lakh from her brother. When she returned on April 1 without the money, her husband first beat her and then tried to slash her face with a blade.

title: Women's march across the country against violence
og_title: Women's march across the country against violence
content: PUNE: If women don’t rise now, atrocities against them will only get stronger, personifying the verses of theatre activist Safdar Hashmi, women across India took to the streets on Thursday to vow to vote out the “anti-women, anti-worker and anti- Dalit”. The march was carried out in key cities including Pune. In Pune the march started from Shramik bhavan near Pune Municipal Corporation to Balgandharva chowk where women were shouting slogans of freedom so that parties contesting Lok Sabha elections understand the issues and take up the same in their manifestos. Organisers of the March told TOI that the Women March for Change was happening across 20 states in over a 100 places. The march is an open call to women voters to come out and counter the blatant attack on the Idea of India, the already shrinking space of dissent, to save our institutions and our democratic character. With the upcoming elections, the Women for Change campaign plans to reach out to women voters to come out and vote for whoever they feel will do justice to their issues best, stated the members of the campaign. The spirit unity was evident as women from across segments marched hand in hand -- from working class women ,including domestic workers, home-based workers, manual scavengers, to university students and civil society members -- singing in solidarity and sending out a powerful message to the existing government and other political parties contesting the polls. The women alleged that the present schemes announced for the women were a mere eyewash. "The funds of Beti Bachao, Beti Padhao, the maximum funds for the scheme were used for publicity, for the Ujjwala scheme, the government acted as if they are doing the women a favour from our own money, today the women have finally come out openly, to call out the government on its bluff” , said the activists in their speeches Issues of the communalisation and increasing atrocities against women were also highlighted. The women also highlighted the issues of marginalised sections, the dalit and the Muslim women who have suffered the most violence under political parties, “Not just women, the violence against the LGBTQ community and trans men and women has seen an unprecedented increase, but there has been nothing done by political parties who have kept mum on all these matters,''stated another member. The recent report assessing over 100 affidavits of those contesting elections, there are many who have declared criminal cases against them that includes violence against women and this the parties have to be answerable. "How can they push for such candidates?''they question

title: Women, transgenders demand a violence-free society
og_title: Women, transgenders demand a violence-free society
content: As the run-up to the elections heats up, a section of Bengaluru’s women, transgenders and other thinkerati gathered to voice their concerns for a free society. More than a hundred people gathered around the State Bank of Mysore Circle, expressing that they want to live in a world that is devoid of hatred and negativity. The gathering had a mix of people from the arts and film industry, alongside social workers, academicians, working professionals and more. Filmmaker Kavitha Lankesh , who was a prominent voice at the rally, says, “We need to reclaim our republic and assert our rights guaranteed by the Constitution. The current society is filled with a lot of hate and negativity, and we are here to demand a free society that allows us to live at our will and have no hatred.” She also recalled how the intolerant society was a reason for the assassination of her sister, journalist Gauri Lankesh . Others spotted at the rally included transgender activist Akkai Padmashali, who also voiced the concern over excessive hate politics creeping in everywhere and stood up for a society that requires no hatred. The rally had many women taking centrestage for a couple of minutes each. They read out poems and shared stories — all in the hope for a freer and a more inclusive society.

title: Violence, faulty EVMs mar Andhra polls
og_title: Violence, faulty EVMs mar Andhra polls
content: Vijayawada/Hyderabad: The acrimony between TDP and YSRCP did not end even as the last vote was cast for Lok Sabha and assembly elections in Andhra Pradesh on Thursday in the first phase of the general elections. AP was headed for a new record as voting continued till late in the night in 400 polling stations across the state and was likely to cross midnight. Even as Election Commission officials put the provisional voting percentage at 74, chief minister and TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu demanded repolling in at least 30% of the booths. He alleged that EVMs had malfunctioned in a large number of constituencies and held YSRCP responsible for widespread violence on polling day. YSRCP chief Y S Jaganmohan Reddy on the other hand directly held Naidu responsible for the violence and even called him a monster. “Naidu is a demon who is responsible for all the violence that took place during the polls,” Jagan said. “He knew he was losing in the elections and tried every means to prevent people from voting.” He also said that the high turnout could mean only one thing: “YSRCP will get a landslide. I won’t say how many seats we will win, but the YSRCP will form the next government.” Setting the tone for opposition leaders for the remaining phases of the general election, Naidu said that the malfunctioning EVMs only strengthened his doubts that the devices could be tampered with. The commission, however, said only 381 EVMs out of 96,000 across the state malfunctioned and the problem was rectified at all places. AP chief electoral officer (CEO) Gopal Krishna Dwivedi denied reports of largescale malfunction of EVMs. Naidu, meanwhile, shot off four letters to the commission and director general of police (DGP) over malfunctioning EVMs and violent incidents at various places in the state. In the letter to Dwivedi, he alleged that nearly 30% EVMs malfunctioned and three hours were wasted at many booths. After casting his vote at Undavalli near Vijayawada, he told reporters that it was time to return to the ballot paper. “In some cases, voters were pressing cycle (TDP’s symbol) button, but the vote was going to fan (YSRCP symbol),” he alleged. In his complaint to the commission Naidu alleged that EVMs did not work till 9.30 am, leaving voters standing in queue for more than two hours at many places. He reiterated his demand for introduction of paper ballots to ensure that there was no “tampering” of the votes polled. Women even protested in Vijayawada after EVMs at polling stations in Moghalrajpuram did not work for a long time. They shouted slogans against the commission. Some voters also complained that they were not able to vote as booth managers did not allow them to take mobile phones into the booth and there was no facility to leave them outside. BOX EVM hold up CEO AP chief electoral officer (CEO) Gopal Krishna Dwivedi had to return without voting when the EVM of his polling booth failed to function. However, he returned later and cast his vote.

title: Kolkata: Day after violence, lawyers abstain from work, seek removal of senior cops
og_title: Kolkata: Day after violence, lawyers abstain from work, seek removal of senior cops
content: KOLKATA/HOWRAH: Members of The Calcutta High Court Bar Association and its lawyers’ wings — Bar Library Club and Incorporated Law Society — abstained from legal work on Thursday in protest against Wednesday’s “brutal police action” on their colleagues in Howrah court. On Thursday morning, a writ petition was filed before Calcutta High Court’s Chief Justice TBN Radhakrishnan demanding the immediate removal of DCDD Anant Nag, ADC Vabna Gupta and ACP Gulam Sarrowar. Later, senior advocate Bikash Bhattacharya mentioned the matter before the chief justice urging the court to take suo motu cognizance of Wednesday’s incident. The Chief Justice said reports on the incident has been sought from the state chief secretary and the Howrah district judge. In the afternoon, the Bar Council of West Bengal sent out an appeal to Bar Associations of courts across the state to observe a cease-work from Friday to Monday to demand the immediate arrest of policemen involved in Wednesday’s alleged attack on Howrah court lawyers. The Bar Council also urged lawyers across Bengal to wear black badges in protest on Friday. Bar council chairman Ashok Deb and members Prasun Datta and Uttam Majumdar also said the council will meet at 4 pm on Monday to review the situation. Howrah Criminal Bar Association secretary Gautam Chatterjee said: “Rapid Action Force (RAF) personnel entered the Howrah court premise and beat up lawyers present inside then. Some lawyers sustained head injuries. They also badly damaged eminent lawyer Prabhat Kumar Ray’s statue.” Ray is the father of state minister and Howrah Trinamool leader Arup Ray, himself a lawyer of the court. Wearing black badges, lawyers of Howrah court organised a procession and sat in dharna demanding immediate removal of the three IPS officers of Howrah City Police. Downtown Howrah — the area around M.G. Road of Kolkata’s sister city — had witnessed mayhem on Wednesday when lawyers of Howrah court and employees of Howrah Municipal Corporation (HMC) fought a pitched battle, triggered over the parking of a lawyer’s bike inside the HMC premise. Arup Ray, however, said, “I do not think police damaged my father’s statue. This is the handiwork of some outsiders, all miscreants. I want an impartial inquiry into the incident under the Howrah District Judge.” Howrah police commissioner Vishal Garg refused to comment on the issue on the ground that it was sub judice. A section of Howrah Municipal Corporation workers, meanwhile, observed a cease-work in protest against Wednesday’s violence. Gurupuda Chatterjee, Municipal Employees’ Union president said, “The way HMC employees were assaulted by lawyers over illegal parking by them, we will continue our protest.” HMC commissioner Bijin Krishna said: “We had issued a clear notification long ago that outsiders cannot park their cars or bikes within the premise of HMC headquarters. The accused lawyer refused to heed our security guard’s objection and tried to park his bike within the premise of HMC headquarters. When my guard protested, the accused physically assaulted him. A group lawyers later barged into HMC headquarters and assaulted employees of the license and health departments. The condition of two of our employees is serious. I have lodged an FIR against some unknown lawyers.”

title: Duo behind audio clip which sparked violence held
og_title: Duo behind audio clip which sparked violence held
content: A special police team arrested two people in Chennai and Thanjavur on Thursday night for recording an abusive audio in Singapore about a particular community and spreading it through WhatsApp leading to largescale violence by the community members at Ponnamaravathi in Pudukottai district and some parts of Madurai. What is surprising is that the duo belonged to the aggrieved community itself. They admitted to the police that they created and spread the audio to provoke their members into “regaining our community pride”. The team led by additional deputy superintendents of police Elango and Anbalagan arrested G Selvakumar, 34, a resident of Manjavayal near Pattukottai in Thanjavur district, working in Singapore. He had returned to Chennai on Thursday night where the police arrested him at the international airport there. The police also arrested his accomplice C Vasanth, 30, from Pattukottai for inciting Selvakumar to create the hate audio about their community and their women. The police tracked them down by identifying an add-on WhatsApp account from which the audio originated. Selvakumar, at the behest of Vasanth, made two of his friends speak ill of the community and recorded it on phone at Westlite area in Singapore on April 14. The former spread the audio through Vasanth on April 17. The audio went viral and triggered violence at Ponnamaravathi and surrounding areas from the night of April 18. As the content of the audio created an impression that it was an attempt to malign the image of their community by those from another community, thousands of people from the community had launched a protest. They vandalized government and private vehicles besides blocking the road and throwing traffic out of gear on April 19 at Ponnmaravathi and nearby areas. .

title: Man hits wife for talking to neighbours
og_title: Man hits wife for talking to neighbours
content: AHMEDABAD: A 40-year-old woman from the Vastrapur area of the city on Tuesday filed a complaint of domestic violence against her husband, as he would allegedly assault her for talking to neighbours or relatives. The complainant told police that she got married to the accused in May 2008. They have three children. On Tuesday evening, her husband took the children out and did not return till late in the night. When he came, she asked him where he had gone. This did not go down well with him and he banged her head against a wall. A neighbour rushed in to rescue her and called the police. The complainant has alleged that her husband would routinely doubt her fidelity would not allow her to talk to anyone. He also confined her to their house and would assault her if she spoke to neighbours or her relatives, the FIR states.

title: ‘Besides Sabarimala, CPM violence to dot campaign’
og_title: ‘Besides Sabarimala, CPM violence to dot campaign’
content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Instead of relying only on the Sabarimala issue to make inroads into LDF and UDF strongholds, the BJP would also focus on the ‘dreadful violence being perpetrated by the CPM’ and the good work being done by the central government, said party leader and Union defence minister Nirmala Sitharaman . “In Kerala, one of the important issues, which the BJP will take up is the CPM’s terrible inheritance of violence and the kind of total chaotic situation which prevails here,” she told reporters here on Monday. She was launching the election campaign of party candidate Kummanam Rajasekharan . The violence perpetrated against RSS and BJP workers in Kerala has increased significantly and CPM cadres have been functioning alongside police like they did in West Bengal, she alleged. Sitharaman, who later addressed a campaign rally, is the first among BJP’s national leaders to campaign in Kerala.“Is this democracy? Is there a kind of environment here for political parties to function fearlessly, or for people to go to polling booths or public meetings held by a party which they do not like,” she asked. Asserting that the elections were important ‘for keeping the momentum the economy gained since 2014, for a clean administration that took care of all sections of society and for continuing the comprehensive approach of reaching out to all’, Sitharaman said a vote to ‘lotus’ would be a direct vote to elect PM Narendra Modi back again. “We are reaching out to people to make them understand how important it is to bring back Modi government in the interest of the country. This is the spirit of our campaign,” Sitharaman also said the party made a detailed study with groups working at the grassroots-level and took pains to choose best candidate available for each constituency. “There’s no doubt that party has picked and chosen the best candidates available, and Kummanam Rajasekharan is one among them,” she added.

title: Two held for recording, sharing abusive audio that triggered violence in parts of Tamil Nadu
og_title: Two held for recording, sharing abusive audio that triggered violence in parts of Tamil Nadu
content: TRICHY: A special team of police arrested two men on Thursday night for recording and spreading an abusive audio about a particular community and spreading it through WhatsApp which led to violence at Ponnamaravathi in Pudukkottai district and in some parts of Madurai. The accused belonged to the same community in question. They admitted to have created and spread the audio to provoke their community people to regain their pride. The police team, led by additional deputy superintendents of police Elango and Anbalagan, arrested G Selvakumar, 34, a resident of Manjavayal near Pattukkottai in Thanjavur district, who works in Singapore . Police arrested Selvakumar when he landed at Chennai international airport on Thursday night. The police also arrested his accomplice, C Vasanth, 30, of Pattukottai for inciting him to create the audio about their own community. Selvakumar, at the behest of Vasanth, made two of his friends to speak ill of the community and recorded it on phone in Westlite area in Singapore on April 14. Selvakumar shared the audio with Vasanth on April 17. He posted it on instant messaging apps. The audio went viral and triggered violence in Ponnamaravathi and surrounding areas from the night on April 18. Thousands of people from the community protested and vandalised the government and private vehicles on April 19. Tension prevailed for two more days before it spread to some parts of Madurai where the community people protested by blocking roads. Inspector general of police, central zone, V Varadharaju said that the police teams were on the lookout for two persons speaking in the audio clip and one more person in Thanjavur who was instrumental in spreading the audio locally.

title: Amid high turnout, Bengal violence claims one life
og_title: Amid high turnout, Bengal violence claims one life
content: KOLKATA: A 52-year-old man was killed in Murshidabad , becoming Bengal’s first casualty of the 2019 polls, as five seats in the state voted in the third phase of the general elections on Tuesday. Turnout was high, with all five seats — Balurghat, Malda Uttar, Malda Dakshin, Murshidabad and Jangipur — recording at least 75% polling. But Abdul Kalam Tiarul Shiekh’s violent death stood out, prompting the Election Commission to seek a report from the district administration. In Malda, a presiding officer was removed from duty by the state chief electoral officer for casting bogus votes. “We are investigating the incident. We are not yet sure whether the clash was a result of a family feud or political rivalry. Three people, including main accused Lalu Shiekh, have been arrested,” additional director-general (law and order) Siddhinath Gupta said. Murshidabad Congress candidate Abu Hena claimed that Sheikh was from his party. Trinamool candidate Abu Taher said the death was unfortunate but his party supporters, too, came under attack. “How could this happen in the presence of central forces?” he asked. Alleged Trinamool goons tore open Tiarul’s belly with machetes, less than 400 metres from a sensitive booth manned by central forces, as he was walking back home with son Mahtab Sheikh after voting. “Trinamool goons Lalu Sheikh and Anroon started abusing us when we came out of the booth. My father didn’t respond. They hit us with bamboo poles. My dad fell down. They dragged my father away and tore open his belly with a machete,” Mahtab said.

title: Lankan in city frets over brother’s fate
og_title: Lankan in city frets over brother’s fate
content: KOLKATA: The coordinated blasts in Colombo on Easter Sunday has left Maya Rawat perplexed. The Sri Lankan, married to an Indian entrepreneur — Dinesh Rawat — for nearly four decades, resides in Kolkata, but spends a few months with her family in Sri Lanka every year. Back in the city after a three-month trip to Colombo, Maya said she did not have any inkling of communal tension that could have led to the deadly blasts. “Sri Lanka saw a lot of violence and blasts during the Tamil uprising. But ever since the LTTE was crushed 10 years ago, the island nation has been an oasis of peace . This allowed tourism to flourish. The country has progressed on several fronts. Both Christians and Muslims in Colombo have lived peacefully,” said Maya, whose brother’s house is within half a kilometre of the three hotels that were targeted by suicide bombers. “Though there has been some friction between Buddhist monks and Muslims, it has been nothing like the trouble between Buddhists and Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar. I don’t believe the genesis of these blasts was in Sri Lanka,” she added. She has not been able to get in touch with family members as the Sri Lankan government suspended internet and phone services in the wake of the attacks. The government justified the suspension, citing it necessary to tackle the spread of false news and information that could fan ethnic tension. St Anthony’s Shrine in Kochchikade, Colombo, which was one of the three churches targeted in the coordinated attacks, is situated 1.5km from her brother’s residence. Maya recounted how people from various religions, including Islam, visit the 175-year-old Catholic church, popularly known as the ‘church of miracles’, to seek blessings. “This is why the attack reeks of outsiders’ involvement,” Maya reasoned. Last month’s mosque attack in Christchurch, New Zealand, saw at least 50 people murdered after a white supremacist went on a shooting rampage. The carnage began at lunchtime on a Friday, when mosques were full of worshippers. Many believe the attacks on Easter Sunday when churches in Sri Lanka were thronging with worshippers was a retaliation of the Christchurch carnage. In a special session of the Sri Lankan parliament on Tuesday, state minister of defence Ruwan Wijewardene said investigators were probing links between the local jihadist group National Thowheed Jamath and Jamaat-ul-Mujahideen. Later, Islamic State claimed responsibility for the strikes that left 321 dead and more than 500 injured. Wijewardene also noted the Easter Sunday bombings could have been a retaliation for the terrorist attacks on two New Zealand mosques last month. Maya’s husband Dinesh, however, did not rule out underlying tensions between Buddhist monks and Muslims leading to the terror strike. “There have been sporadic incidents of right wing Buddhist monks targeting Muslims in Dehiwala and Kotahena localities. For years, Muslims have been at the receiving end. Tension has been simmering between the communities, but violence of this magnitude was not expected,” he said. But then why target Christians who make up barely 7% of the 22-million population? Dinesh reasoned that had Muslims targeted Sinhalese, they could have been wiped out just like the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE), the militant organisation that had waged war for a separate state for over three decades before it was decimated in a major assault by the Lankan army.

title: Constable, home guard injured in mob attack
og_title: Constable, home guard injured in mob attack
content: HYDERABAD: A home guard and a constable from Langer Houz and Narsingi police station, respectively, were injured during a mob attack on Sunday at a funeral. Officials said the incident occurred during the funeral of a suicide victim, Krithika Reddy , who had hanged herself at her husband’s house in Narsingi on Saturday morning. She was married 40 days ago and was depressed because of her father’s ill health. “Many people had arrived from Vikarabad district — the deceased’s native place — for the funeral on Sunday. Seeing a huge crowd, we asked Langer Houz police officers to assist us. After the cremation, the mob attacked Krithika’s husband, Rama Krishna ,” said Narsingi sub-inspector, KM Raghavendra. The mob began pelting stones at them. Aamir, a home guard from Langer Houz police station, was injured after a stone hit him on the head. Yadaiah, a constable of Narsingi police station, sustained a minor injury. “Aamir was admitted to Sairam Hospital and a case is being registered under Section 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter a public servant from his duty) of IPC. We are yet to detain anyone,” said Langer Houz inspector, Srinivas.

title: Haryana: Surjewala targets BJP over Panchkula violence as Congress' Nirmal Singh files nomination
og_title: Haryana: Surjewala targets BJP over Panchkula violence as Congress' Nirmal Singh files nomination
content: KURUKSHETRA: Congress candidate from Kurukshetra Nirmal Singh filed his nomination papers on Tuesday, accompanied by Congress leaders - including former MP Naveen Jindal, Congress spokesman Randeep Singh Surjewala and Chitra Sarwara (Nirmal’s daughter). Before going for the nomination, Nirmal Singh paid obeisance at several temples in Kurukshetra and Gurdwara Patshahi Chevin and Gurdwara Neeldhari in Kurukshetra followed by a public gathering. Nirmal Singh said, “The Kurukshetra has the potential of being developed as a world level tourist spot and Congress will make the efforts to develop it. I am confident of winning from here as I have already started to receive love from the people of Kurukshetra.” While addressing the gathering, Surjewala said “Time has come to expose the lies of Prime Minister and Haryana chief minister who had made false promises during their rallies in Kurukshetra. The BJP leaders are not talking about giving jobs and 50 per cent profit on the cost of production to farmers and where are ache din? The BJP has been trying to end the relation of commission agents and farmers. Modi and Khattar have been disrespecting this state and particularly Kurukshetra with their wrong policies and poor governance.” “The BJP has not given respect to its Dalit leaders in the party and we all have seen that. They claim about giving jobs on merit, but the fact is that the jobs and papers are being sold,” he added and also mentioned the incidents of Satlok Ashram in Hisar, violence during Jat reservation and killing of Dera followers in Panchkula.” Surjewala said, “The BJP has been trying to gain votes in the name of the Army but the BJP will never succeed. The Army works for the nation and not for any party.” Naveen Jindal said, “My relation with Kurukshetra is not political and I will continue to serve it.” He sought support for Nirmal Singh and said, “I have been given opportunity thrice by the party. We have been getting good support from all the sections of society. Nirmal Singh is a senior leader and we will serve Kurukshetra together.” When he was asked if there was any pressure on him to not to contest, he said, “There was no pressure on me. It is all about time and circumstances.” Meanwhile, Surjewala added, “No one can pressure Naveen or any other Congressmen.”

title: Railway official files domestic violence case
og_title: Railway official files domestic violence case
content: AHMEDABAD: A 26-year-old woman from Gota area of the city, who works as junior engineer in Indian Railways , on Saturday filed a complaint of domestic violence (DV) with Sola High Court Police against her husband and in-laws for constant torturing her since after she got married with her boyfriend in March 2018. The complainant, who currently works in Bhavnagar as junior engineer, married a boy whom she loved since her college days, in a Ghaziabad court on March 27, 2018. After their marriage, the couple shifted to Ajmer in Rajasthan where the woman was working last year. Around a week after their marriage, her husband, who was unemployed, began asking for money from her to fulfil his daily requirements. The man had allegedly taken her debit and credit cards and started spending money on his lavish lifestyle, alleged the complaint, adding that he used to beat her if she ever resisted his spending. As the woman had married against her family’s will, she continued to tolerate tortures of her husband. Moreover, her in-laws also began harassing her for demanding money from her father’s place. Aggrieved with harassment, the complainant returned to her father’s place in August 2018 and also filed an application with Sola High Court police but she later had to strike compromise in the case with her husband as he convinced her that he would take divorce from her and would not harass her. But later, he once again started calling and threatening her due to which she filed the FIR with police.

title: Siyana violence: UP Police tries to nail main accused with their call records
og_title: Siyana violence: UP Police tries to nail main accused with their call records
content: MEERUT: Tightening the noose around the accused named in December 3 Siyana violence , UP Police have in its charge-sheet said that Bajrang Dal convener Yogesh Raj and other key conspirators in the case were in constant contact with each other and exchanged several calls within a span of few hours leading to the violence which claimed two lives, including that of senior police officer Subodh Kumar Singh . The charge-sheet has placed Yogesh Raj and other co-conspirators at scene of crime through technical and forensic evidences. As per the charge-sheet, accused Sachin Ahlawat made a call to Raj at 8.55am on December 3, informing him about an alleged cow-slaughter incident in Bulandshahr’s Mahav village. Based on the call detail record (CDR), police in its charge-sheet claimed that between 9am and 1:26pm, 11 phone calls were exchanged between Raj and other accused Ashish Chauhan, Satish Chandra, Sachin Jat, Pavan, Satyendra and Vishal Tyagi. In these telephonic exchanges, Raj directed the other accused to gather with their supporters at the scene of crime. All this while, the location of Raj shuffled between Nayabas and Siyana. To simplify things, police have also included a ray diagram explaining exchange of conversations among the accused. “It is clear that Sachin Ahlawat alerted Yogesh Raj about the cow slaughter incident in Mahav village on December 3. Upon intimation, the Bajrang Dal worker called others and directed them to reach the scene of crime. Later, the cow carcass was loaded in a tractor trolley and brought to Chingrawati police station,” the charge-sheet says. Meanwhile, Bruno Bhushan, the lawyer for Yogesh Raj and other four other accused, claimed that police have deliberately missed out on other details of the CDR. “Police have only included specific inputs of CDR to back their claim. Yogesh made calls to several senior police officers during the same time. But CDR was never made part of the case diary to ensure this thing never comes out.” He said that Yogesh was also in talks with the police and did not want violence. The Bulandshahr Police had filed the charge-sheet against 38 accused, including Raj and BJP youth wing leader Shikhar Agarwal in March. Out of the 38 accused, five were charge-sheeted for murder. A mob went on rampage on December 3 after a cow carcass was found in a sugarcane field near Mahav village of Siyana in Bulandshahr. Inspector Subodh Kumar Singh, who was posted at Siyana police station, was killed in the attack. A youth, Sumit Kumar, also lost his life during the violence.

title: Security forces put on alert to tackle Maoist violence
og_title: Security forces put on alert to tackle Maoist violence
content: PATNA: Though the number of Maoist-hit districts in the state has reduced from 23 in 2014 Lok Sabha election to 16 now, the Election Commission of India (ECI) is leaving no stone unturned to tackle any move of the rebel outfit to disrupt polls. Patna, Bhojpur, Sheohar, Sitamarhi, Begusarai and Khagaria are some of the districts in the state which will go to polls sans the ‘Maoist-hit’ tag this time. These districts were excluded from the left wing extremism list by the Union ministry of home affairs (MHA) in April last year. In 2018, the state had witnessed minimum Maoist violence when compared to the previous 13 years, thanks to a financial crackdown on top Maoist leaders by the Enforcement Directorate , which attached their movable and immovable properties worth several crores in the state. In August last year, the MHA had declared Aurangabad, Gaya, Jamui and Lakhisarai as 30 left wing extremism-affected districts in the country which record maximum Maoist violence. Aurangabad, Gaya, Jamui and Nawada will go to polls in the first phase on April 11. Chief electoral officer (CEO) H R Srinivasa told TOI over the phone that security forces would remain on full alert even in the districts which are no more considered as Maoist-infested. “We are on high alert. The areas in Jharkhand, which share border with four Maoist-hit constituencies in Bihar, are not going to polls in the first phase. This has to be kept in mind for making security arrangements,” he said. The last two general elections saw large scale Maoist violence in the state. In 2009 LS polls, seven people, including six security personnel, were killed in Maoist violence in the state. In 2014, five security personnel were killed and 16 injured in such attacks. According to data available with officials at the CEO office, a sub-inspector (SI), a magistrate and five constables were killed in Maoist attacks in 2009 general election. Of them, two constables were killed in Gaya, the SI, magistrate and three more constables lost their lives after Maoists triggered a landmine blast in Muzaffarpur. In Motihari too, a police vehicle was damaged in a landmine explosion. However, none died in the incident. In Gaya, five buildings were blown up by the Maoists in 2009. The rebels had also attacked police and polling parties. In Aurangabad, three buildings were blown up by the Maoists and two attacks reported on political leaders. In Rohtas, a police party was attacked. In Jamui also, one building was blown up. During 2014 general election, three security personnel were killed and eight injured in Aurangabad. In Munger, two security personnel were killed and eight injured. Central Reserve Police Force jawans had come under attack in Munger while they were on way to a polling station in Jamui parliamentary constituency.

title: Caste clash: Many booked, search on for duo in video
og_title: Caste clash: Many booked, search on for duo in video
content: PUDUKOTTAI: A day after imposing prohibitory orders under section 144 of CrPC at communal violence-hit Ponnamaravathi in Pudukottai district, police on Saturday registered cases against a large group of protesters for vandalizing public property in the area. Police were, however, still clueless about the two people in conversation in the audio clip. IG Varadharaju said that the police teams were making every attempt to track them down. “We have the video of the group damaging vehicles and throwing stones, based on which we have registered a case against them. The investigation will go on,” inspector general of police (IG), central zone V Varadharaju told TOI. However, he said the FIR had no mention of the number of people involved in the violence. More than 1,000 people of a particular community had carried out the violence in which police vehicles, government buses and private vehicles on the road were damaged and pelted with stones in Ponnamaravathi town. Many had also blocked the Pudukottai – Ponnamaravathi stretch on Friday causing bus services to come to a halt. Violence hit Ponnamaravathi taluk, which comprises nearly 30 villages, in the late hours on Thursday as people from a numerically dominant community in the area turned their wrath against the police for not arresting two people who spread a derogatory audio clip against them and their women on WhatsApp . Out of fear over likely violence, there was no operation of buses from Pudukottai to Alangudi, Gandharvakottai, Karambakudi, Aranthangi and a few other areas since Friday morning. Later in the day, the police allowed the buses to operate to some areas with the policemen on board security. Pudukottai district administration has ordered temporary shutdown of Tasmac wine shops throughout the district on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Journalist shot dead during riots in Northern Ireland
og_title: Journalist shot dead during riots in Northern Ireland
content: DERRY: A journalist was shot dead during riots in Northern Ireland in what police on Friday were treating as a terrorist incident following the latest upsurge in violence to shake the troubled region. "Lyra McKee was murdered during orchestrated violence in Creggan last night," assistant chief constable Mark Hamilton said in a statement. McKee, 29, had earlier posted an image that appeared to be from the riots in the Creggan housing estate in the city of Londonderry, also known as Derry, accompanied by the words "Derry tonight. Absolute madness." Images of the unrest posted on social media showed a car and van ablaze and hooded individuals throwing petrol bombs and fireworks at police vehicles. "A single gunman fired shots in a residential area of the city and as a result wounded Ms McKee," said Hamilton, adding that police believed the gunman was a "violent dissident republican". "We are treating this as a terrorist incident and we have launched a murder enquiry," he added. McKee had written for The Atlantic magazine and Buzzfeed News and was named by Forbes Magazine in 2016 as one of their "30 under 30" outstanding figures in media, according to her literary agent Janklow & Nesbit. Leona O'Neill, a reporter with the Belfast Telegraph , said she saw McKee get hurt. "I was standing beside this young woman when she fell beside a police Land Rover tonight in Creggan #Derry. I called an ambulance for her but police put her in the back of their vehicle and rushed her to hospital where she died. Just 29 years old. Sick to my stomach tonight," she tweeted. Thursday's unrest raised memories of past decades of violence in Northern Ireland. Ireland's Prime Minister Leo Varadkar warned that "we cannot allow those who want to propagate violence, fear and hate to drag us back to the past". His British counterpart Theresa May said the killing was "shocking and truly senseless". In Brussels, a European Commission spokesman condemned the "terrible incident". "We condemn such violence, and we are confident that the UK authorities will ascertain the exact circumstances of this tragic event," he said. Visiting US house of representatives speaker Nancy Pelosi joined in a minute's silence for McKee, saying it was "especially poignant", being held on Good Friday. The violence came in the run-up to the Easter weekend, when Republicans opposed to the British presence in Northern Ireland mark the anniversary of a 1916 uprising against British rule. A car-bombing and the hijacking of two vans in Londonderry earlier this year were also blamed on a dissident paramilitary group. Michelle O'Neill, the deputy leader of Irish republican party Sinn Fein, condemned the killing. "My heart goes out to the family of the young woman shot dead by so-called dissidents," she wrote on Twitter. "This was an attack on the community, an attack on the peace process and an attack on the Good Friday Agreement," the peace deal that largely brought an end to violence on the island exactly 21 years ago, she added, calling for calm. Arlene Foster, leader of the Democratic Union Party, which is in favour of Britain's presence in Northern Ireland, described the death as "heartbreaking news". "A senseless act. A family has been torn apart. Those who brought guns onto our streets in the 70s, 80s & 90s were wrong. It is equally wrong in 2019. No one wants to go back," she wrote on Twitter. The Good Friday Agreement in 1998 largely brought an end to three decades of sectarian bloodshed in Northern Ireland between republican and unionist paramilitaries, as well as British armed forces, in a period known as "the Troubles". Some 3,500 people were killed in the conflict — many at the hands of the Irish Republican Army (IRA). Police have blamed a group called the New IRA for the flare-up in violence in recent months. Some have expressed fears that recent attacks could be a sign that paramilitaries are seeking to exploit the current political turbulence over Northern Ireland and its border with the Republic of Ireland caused by Brexit. Londonderry was the scene of one of the darkest episodes in the Troubles in 1972, known as Bloody Sunday, when British troops opened fire on a civil rights demonstration and killed 13 people. A 14th victim later died of his wounds. A former British soldier was charged with murder last month over the killings.

title: Ahmedabad: Man in void marriage ordered to maintain wife
og_title: Ahmedabad: Man in void marriage ordered to maintain wife
content: AHMEDABAD: A local court ordered a farmer to pay his wife maintenance under provisions of the Domestic Violence Act , after the court observed that the couple’s marriage was void. Laljibhai and Janakben Vaghela were married in December 15 and got their marriage registered in Nadiad. They got married while their earlier marriages were subsisting, without divorcing their previous spouses. The couple lived together for a year and had a daughter. After matrimonial discord, the woman was forced to leave her husband’s home with the infant girl. She filed a complaint under domestic violence laws and sought maintenance and compensation. Before the court, the husband disputed their marriage and accused the woman of threatening him with false cases to make the documents. The court had to decide whether the couple had co-habited and domestic violence really took place. The court answered these questions in the affirmative and ordered Vaghela to pay the woman and her daughter Rs 7,500 as monthly maintenance, besides Rs 10,000 compensation for domestic violence. Additional civil judge at the Mirzapur rural court Abhishek Sahu said, “As for the maintenance of the applicant, it may be seen that the marriage between the parties is a void marriage . And thus, the applicant is not eligible for proper maintenance from the opponent. However, the applicant will be required to be given maintenance for the part which she has been suffering due to domestic violence.” The court said that while Vaghela had his own house and agricultural land, the woman had nothing much to prove his income. However, the fact that they lived together as husband and wife entitled her to maintenance because domestic violence was proved. The woman has to bear the burden of the child and the expense of the rented house after being driven out of her matrimonial home. This led the court to pass a “reasonable order” keeping in mind the residential requirements and maintenance of the woman and her child.

title: EC draws up new plan to counter violence, rigging in Tripura East
og_title: EC draws up new plan to counter violence, rigging in Tripura East
content: GUWAHATI: If the elections to the Vellore Lok Sabha constituency were cancelled because of illegal cash flow, polls to Tripura East had to be deferred because of large-scale political violence and systemic lapses in the polling process to the other parliamentary seat in the state, Tripura West. Polls in politically volatile Tripura have never been free of trouble. In 2018, the state registered 589 cases of political violence, the highest so far. The ruling BJP government, which came to power in March last year, claimed the spike was only because more cases were being booked by police. This time, however, the extent of disruptions and violence forced the Election Commission (EC) to defer polls to the Tripura East Lok Sabha constituency from April 18 to April 23. Since the announcement of the Lok Sabha election, at least 35 cases of political violence were reported in Tripura by Congress and CPM. As the elections drew near, the allegations grew more serious. Congress candidate from Tripura West Subal Bhowmik was attacked, allegedly by 50 BJP workers. CPM's re-contesting MP from Tripura West Sankar Prasad Datta also alleged that BJP workers had attacked his convoy at Sonamura. When the election to Tripura West was conducted on April 11, both Congress and CPM claimed 464 polling booths had been compromised because of large-scale rigging and voter intimidation by BJP workers. At least 10 cases of booth capturing have already been registered. Finally, just before the polls to tribal-majority Tripura East, voters in several areas of the constituency were greeted with a handwritten note, with a severed chicken's head hanging beside it, threatening people against voting on April 18 lest they should meet the same fate. On April 16, the EC announced the election had been deferred. The decision was taken after receiving the President's approval, based on a report from the returning officer of the constituency where he "expressed serious apprehension that miscreant elements may thwart the polling process in the constituency, based on ground and intelligence reports and has requested for additional Central Armed Police Forces." "We came across media reports and videos on social media narrating how voting took place in the first phase (in Tripura West). There was no semblance of any order. You can't have the world's biggest democratic process function like this," said 60-year-old Jyotirmoy Deb, a businessman who will vote from Tripura East. "Now, we are hopeful the Election Commission will do everything possible to make sure voters like me can exercise their franchise," he added. The EC, on its part, has employed two broad strategies to make polling possible in the constituency - additional deployment of central paramilitary forces and cracking down on disrupters. Additional DGP Rajiv Singh, under whose watch as a nodal officer Tripura West went to the polls, has been transferred. In addition, the poll panel has started filing FIRs against poll officials - presiding officers, poll officials, polling agents and political activists - whose activities led to the disorder. "We have sent out a message to the people that if anything goes wrong on polling day, whoever is behind it will be held accountable. Anyone, irrespective of position or identity, who tries to create trouble will be booked. Police have already started booking trouble-makers," special chief electoral officer of Tripura, PR Bhattacharjee, told TOI. The poll panel has initiated confidence-building measures and stepped up patrolling. It now hopes more people will step out and vote. "The situation is conducive to conducting the election. There is a visible change in the Tripura East constituency. The number of complaints have gone down and are not of serious nature. Additional forces will be reaching here in the next few hours," he added. As for Tripura West, alleged irregularities in polling to which spurred the decision to reschedule the Tripura East election, the EC is still working out how re-polling will be conducted. "A review (of the first phase election process) is going on ... I think we might have to conduct repolling but it can be confirmed only after the EC finishes the review and sends a report. The commission is the final authority," Bhattacharjee added. BJP, which initially tried to deflect the debate by claiming this was a "divisive" plan by CPM and Congress and even saying that the opposition parties "confused" the EC with their complaints, sees the edge it has given to its opponents. "Congress and the Left are upbeat. They complained against us and the polls got deferred, giving them more time to campaign," a BJP leader said. The BJP candidate from Tripura East, Rebati Mohan Tripura, on the other hand, was on Thursday served a notice for exceeding the spending limit. The saffron party is already on the back foot in the tribal-majority seat, where it is up against its own ally Indigenous People's Front of Tripura (IPFT), which holds five of the 13 tribal-reserved assembly segments, and refused to bow out of the contest in deference to its senior partner in the ruling coalition. Congress, meanwhile, has fielded a royal family member - Maharajkumari Pragya Debburman, daughter of late Kirit Bikram Kishore Debburman, the last king of Tripura - while CPM has fielded incumbent Jitendra Choudhury, president of the party's tribal wing.

title: ‘Social media spreading hatred in rural Gujarat’
og_title: ‘Social media spreading hatred in rural Gujarat’
content: AHMEDABAD: A report on communal violence in 2018, Deepening Roots of Communalism in Gujarat, by a city-based human rights organization, Buniyaad, states that 46% of incidents of communal violence in rural Gujarat in 2018 were triggered by the spread of hate messages through social media. The study says 13 incidents of communal violence were reported in rural Gujarat in 2018. “Communal riots in the past were restricted to urban areas. The spread of communal hatred and violence to rural areas has become evident in the last couple of years and continued in 2018. Social media platforms are a tool to spread hatred along religious lines,” the study says. In 2018, communal violence was reported in Kherda (Anand), Halvad (Morbi), Matar (Kheda), Chhatral (Gandhinagar), Sherpur (Idar), Vadali (Sabarkantha), Vaktapur (Sabarkantha), Sanjeli (Dahod) and Eral (Panchmahal) villages besides Fatehpura, Waghodiya and Nyay Mandir areas of Vadodara district, according to the study. “In six of these 13 incidents, social media had a key role in the spread of hate messages which eventually triggered communal tension and violence,” said Hozefa Ujjaini, who leads Buniyaad. “For instance, at Fatehpura in Vadodara, an alleged incident of stone-pelting at a Ram Navami procession, triggered a riot between two communities. According to locals, unidentified miscreants hurled stones at the procession, which brushed the statue of Lord Ram mounted atop an open truck. Provocative messages were then circulated on WhatsApp, which fuelled the riots,” he added. Analysis of communal incidents in Gujarat revealed that religious festivals, processions, rallies, inter-religious relationships, derogatory/controversial songs, eve-teasing and hate speech are trigger-points for communal riots. Gujarat had 1.06 crore internet subscribers in rural areas as on December 2018, according to data from the Telecom Regulatory Authority of India (TRAI). Explaining the impact of false messages on the rural populace, sociologist Gaurang Jani said, “Social media has given the rural population a platform to present their views. However, the mindset of rural people is usually quite conservative and therefore, fake news or messages on issues like inter-religious marriages go viral and can spark conflict very easily.” The study also analysed the financial losses incurred. Based on data from FIRs and investigation by the researchers, losses to the tune of Rs 2.62 crore were caused in these 13 incidents.

title: Stone pelting in Nizamabad district during religious procession
og_title: Stone pelting in Nizamabad district during religious procession
content: HYDERABAD: During a religious procession of a community in Nizamabad district on Friday, some of the members of this community pelted stones and damaged the property of people of another community on Friday night. Some of the videos of the stone pelting showed that police were not in control of the situation as the mob damaged parked cars and auto rickshaws on the road besides specifically targeting a commercial building by pelting stones on it. There have been allegations of police inaction in controlling the stone pelters when some persons were damaging the property while shouting religious slogans. Senior police officers later rushed in additional forces and brought the situation under control by making some intervention. The rally was first allowed to be completed without any further trouble and district police claimed that action will be taken against those who were involved in stone pelting.

title: Chandigarh: Violence outside Sector 7 pub, 4 held
og_title: Chandigarh: Violence outside Sector 7 pub, 4 held
content: CHANDIGARH: Police have arrested four persons, including bouncers of a pub, for allegedly assaulting and rioting at Sector 7 on Thursday. The accused are Sumneek Singh and Shubhdeep Singh, both residents of Sector 70, Mohali , Suraj, a resident of Kharar and Sayeed, a resident of Sector 20. Sarabjot Singh, who works as head, security, Social, Sector 7, alleged Sumneek and two more men entered the eatery in a drunken condition. After a party, they started teasing a girl waiting outside. When a bouncer tried to stop him, they attacked him. They also damaged a vehicle parked outside the pub. Later, they called up their friends and attacked bouncers with sticks and baseball bats, Sarabjot, a resident of Sector 78, Mohali , alleged. Sumneek, however, alleged five to seven persons, including bouncers, attacked him with sticks. Sumneek alleged he went to the pub with a woman friend. “When I was dancing with her, one person shoved me aside and started dancing with her. He passed comments at her and abused me. When I resisted, he called the bouncers and all of them assaulted me. Later, his brother also came to the site and attacked me with some sharp-edged weapon and also took Rs 14,000 for striking a compromise,” he alleged. However, the other party claimed they took Rs 14,000 as compensation for the damages done to the eatery. Sector 26 police reached the spot and took the injured to a hospital. After getting complaints from both groups, Sector 26 police registered cross FIR’s under the sections of assault and rioting against both parties and arrested four persons.

title: Beliefs lead to violence
og_title: Beliefs lead to violence

title: Derogatory audio about community sparks violence in Tamil Nadu village
og_title: Derogatory audio about community sparks violence in Tamil Nadu village
content: PUDUKKOTTAI: A derogatory audio message about a particular community led to violence at Ponnamaravathi in Pudukkottai district of Tamil Nadu on Friday with people from the community throwing stones at policemen, damaging the government buses and police vehicles. Prohibitory orders under Section 144 of the CrPc was imposed in Ponnamaravathi taluk to prevent further escalation of tension. Tension gripped Poonamaravathi town and surrounding areas after more than 5,000 men and women from the community converged in front of the local police station demanding arrest of miscreants who spread the audio clip against their community. Prior to that, they damaged the vehicles parked on roadsides. Though superintendent of police (SP S Selvaraj intervened and eased the situation, the protests became violent when the angry mob tried to gather near Ponnamaravathi police station and threw stones at police vehicles and the policemen. The incident left four police vehicles and two government buses damaged and two policemen injured. The police resorted to lathicharge and brought the violence under control in the afternoon. As news spread, tension again surfaced. Irate people resorted to the blockade by felling trees on Pudukkottai-Ponnamaravathi Road. Traffic was affected on the road. “The issue is under control. We are closely monitoring. The action is on to arrest those indulging in violence,” inspector general of police (IG), central zone V Varadharaju told TOI. He said that they were clueless about the people speaking in the audio message. Deputy inspector general of police, Trichy range, R Lalitha Lakshmi was camping in the area.

title: Andhra Pradesh: Blame game continues in Sattenapalle, cops in quandary
og_title: Andhra Pradesh: Blame game continues in Sattenapalle, cops in quandary
content: GUNTUR: Police in rural district are in a piquant situation as Sattenapalle constituency remained tense on Thursday with both TDP and YSRC leaders exerting pressure on the cops to act tough against the rival camp. Leaders from both parties have been demanding that the police crack the whip against the opponents in connection with the attack on speaker Kodela Sivaprasada Rao on the day of polling at Inumetla village. Although the police lodged cases against both the groups, the pressure from the parties is making their job tough in probing the case. The police are feeling edgy particularly with the surveys on polling trends giving divided opinions. Although the ruling TDP is confident of returning to power, the celebratory mood in the YSRC camp has made the police wary of rushing into action mode. The police have already arrested some of the YSRC activists in connection with the attack on Sivaprasada Rao but they might wait for some more time before going tough with the other accused in the case, including YSRC candidate Ambati Rambabu and senior leader Basu Lingareddy. Similarly, the police booked cases against 22 TDP leaders and activists, including Sivaprasada Rao, following a complaint lodged by YSRC agent Shaik Imam in the Inumetla polling centre. He alleged that Sivaprasada Rao and others barged into the polling centre and threatened them with dire consequences. Sattenapalle DSP Kaleshavali said they have sought video clippings from the polling officials to probe the case. He said they would take further action in the case after getting the evidence. Interestingly, the police booked case against TDP leaders only after YSRC candidate and senior leader Ambati Rambabu issued ultimatum to stage hunger strike against police inaction. In fact, YSRC leaders have complained to chief electoral officer (CEO) on the alleged inaction by the police. “The police should have booked a case suo moto against Sivaprasada Rao and other TDP leaders for forcibly entering the polling booth and trying to rig votes. We have urged the CEO to probe as to what prompted the police to book the case almost three days after the polling,” Rambabu said.

title: Government hospitals told to file FIRs for doctor attacks
og_title: Government hospitals told to file FIRs for doctor attacks
content: NEW DELHI: Delhi government on Tuesday issued a circular directing all state-run hospitals to file an institutional FIR in case of any incident involving abuse or violence by the patients or their attendants. “It will be incumbent on the medical superintendent/director of the institution to ensure an FIR is lodged in such cases by the hospital or institution concerned rather than insisting on the concerned hospital staff to get it lodged,” stated the circular issued by principal secretary (health) Sanjeev Khirwar. “Non-compliance of aforesaid directions will be viewed seriously,” it added. Dr Arun Gupta, head of Delhi Medical Council (DMC), said this was a much-needed directive. “It is the duty of the hospital to protect its employee and fight for him /her if the doctor or any other staff is attacked while on duty,” he said. DMC registrar Girish Tyagi also welcomed the government move. “I had raised this issue with chief secretary Vijay Dev recently, and it was reiterated with other senior members of Delhi Medical Association,” he said. In the last few years, incidence of violence against doctors have increased manifold. Patient perception of injustice within the medical sphere is a key factor, said an expert. “In public hospitals like ours, there’s no profit mongering. We work for 36 hours at a stretch with limited resources, and even after that get abused and assaulted,” said a senior resident at Safdarjung hospital. The hospital witnessed a day-long strike recently against the assault on a junior doctor by a patient and his attendants who allegedly broke the doctor’s nasal bones. The hospital doctor said the attack on them — physical, verbal and through social media — has become a trend. “We have become the favourite bashing boys. No one will go and ask the administration why there are such few ICU beds? They won’t go and ask the government why even after six decades since independence, the disparity in availability of super-specialty health services remains high across different regions,” said Dr Vivek Couksey, former president of the Federation of Resident Doctors’ Association of India.

title: Delhi: Centre blames AAP government for violence during sealing
og_title: Delhi: Centre blames AAP government for violence during sealing
content: NEW DELHI: The Centre on Monday blamed AAP government for the clashes and violence that broke out in Mayapuri following a sealing drive last week. Union urban affairs minister Hardeep Singh Puri said the Centre had no role in this as NGT had passed the order for Delhi Pollution Control Committee to take action against illegal entities and DPCC is under the city government. Puri accused Delhi government of “acting in panic” following the NGT order, and that in a keen jerk reaction, agencies took action against the scrap units, some of which already had permission to operate from the locality. “It (AAP) did not do anything for the past five years. Now, with the NGT saying that officials will be jailed, it went into panic mode and did something illegal...There was lack of responsibility from Delhi government. It did not even stop to see who was allowed and who wasn’t. The directions of NGT was for the Delhi government, not for the Centre,” he said. The minister said DPCC should have taken action in all these years. While some units have the consent to operate, others don’t. The owners of these should have gone to the DPCC and taken permission,” Puri said. He alleged that the Arvind Kejriwal government was busy spreading “fake and false narrative” to shy away from taking responsibility. Puri also claimed that DDA had not received any proposal for earmarking any area for carrying out the scrapping activities. He said though the Delhi master plan does not have any provision for scrap yard or market, the government would consider it once the proposal is forwarded by the city government.

title: 3 killed in Tripura village as poll debate turns violent
og_title: 3 killed in Tripura village as poll debate turns violent
content: AGARTALA: An altercation over which party to support in the Lok Sabha election resulted in the death of three tribals, including a woman, in Manikpur village of Tripura 's Dhalai district, police have said. The incident happened on Saturday. The deceased persons -- identified as Subal Kanti Chakma, 65, Kinachand Chakma, 45, and Hembati Tripura, 39 -- were attacked with sharp-edged weapons. Two others, Murucherra Chakma and Gunodhar Chakma, sustained injuries in the attack. They are in hospital now. Police said some people, who were under the influence of alcohol, got into an election debate, which turned violent after some time. Chhabikanta Chakma, a juvenile, has been arrested in connection with the killings, which took place when the Chakmas were celebrating the Biju festival. Both Congress and BJP have blamed each other for the incident. According to police, when the quarrel over supporting BJP or Congress in the East Tripura seat broke out, Chhabikanta suddenly got agitated and attacked others with a sharp-edged weapon. Later, villagers overpowered the accused and handed him over to police. The bodies were handed over to their families after postmortem. Police said an investigation was on.

title: RSS man held for hartal violence
og_title: RSS man held for hartal violence
content: Thiruvananthapuram: Nedumangad police on Saturday arrested a RSS leader in connection with the case related to attack on Nedumangad municipality councillor Sabu. The accused has been identified as Vidhyadharan, 56, of Ganapathiyankuzhi near Aryanad. He is a Boudhik Shikshan Pramukh of Nedumangad district unit and a Karyavahak of Palode, Kattakkada and Vellanad areas. The attack happened during the hartal observed by right wing organizations on January 3. The police said that Vidhyadharan was arrested on charges of harbouring the suspects, who had hurled bombs at CPM activists and police personnel on the hartal day. The police had registered an attempt to murder case. Nedumangad had witnessed widespread violence during the hartal observed by BJP and RSS to protest against the entry of two women under the age of 50 into Sabarimala Temple. Clashes broke out at several spots when the CPM activists and police intervened to prevent the hartal supporters from forcefully shutting shops and establishments. The hartal supporters even attacked several policemen and hurled explosives at Nedumangad police station when few hartal supporters were taken into custody for resorting to violence.

title: Khyala violence: Third victim dies
og_title: Khyala violence: Third victim dies
content: NEW DELHI: Two days after a man stabbed three members of a family in west Delhi's Khyala, the third victim also succumbed to his injuries. Senior police officers said that the victim, 18-year-old Akash, succumbed to his injuries sustained in the stomach and abdomen on Friday morning. His parents, Sunita and Veeru, died after being attacked by the accused, Mohammed Azad. Following the development, the already tensed area saw locals gathering around the police station and protesting at the scene of events. Before being dispersed by cops, the locals demanded stringent punishment for the accused and also alleged that the local police was negligent in handling the situation. Many locals alleged that illicit activities like sale of hooch and drugs are rampant in the area, which has propelled crime.

title: Minister kin, netas hurt in Kurnool clash
og_title: Minister kin, netas hurt in Kurnool clash
content: Vijayawada: Two voters died due to sunstroke in queue as a series of stone-pelting incidents marred polling in Kurnool district on Thursday. At Ahobilam in Allagadda constituency, TDP and YSRC leaders were involved in a shouting match outside a polling station and that soon turned into stone-pelting. A CRPF constable was injured apart from tourism minister Bhooma Akhila Priya’s husband Bhargav, sister Mounika, YSRC contestant Bijendranath Reddy, independent contestant Kandula Naidu and police personnel in the incident. Polling was stopped and additional forces rushed in. Police had to fire in air to quell the clash. Stone-pelting incidents were also reported from Banaganapalle, Orvakallu, Veldurti, Kurnool, Chagalammari and Kosigi in Kurnool. Polling got delayed for EVM glitches in about 40% polling stations. A 52-year-old woman, Sheik Karimun from Devanur under Midtur mandal and one Boya Pedda Venkateswarlu from Kodumuru, died due to sunstroke. Stone-pelting also took place in Mangalagiri. Vijayawada-West MLA Jaleel Khan was taken into custody for attacking a YSRCP worker and damaging two cars. In Nellore district, polling was peaceful except in Atmakur and Sarvepalli constituencies As complaints poured in seeking repoll in at least 600 polling booths, CEO Gopal Krishna Dwivedi said the EC will take a decision on Friday on repoll.

title: Barring minor tiffs, Godavari districts see calm voting
og_title: Barring minor tiffs, Godavari districts see calm voting
content: Vijayawada: Barring minor incidents in Eluru and Denduluru assembly constituencies, polling was peaceful in East and West Godavari districts. Supporters of TDP’s Eluru candidate and MLA Badeti Kota Ramarao and YSRC candidate Alla Kalikrishna Srinivas alias Nani clashed at the polling station. In Dendulur, where sitting MLA and TDP candidate Chintamaneni Prabhakar’s supporters and YSRC candidate Kotaru Abbayi Chowdary’s supporters engaged in verbal abuse and clashed. Police finally cleared them from polling station to restore peace. In Tuni assembly constituency of East Godavari district, where finance minister Yanamala Ramakrishnudu’s son Krishnudu is contesting, TDP leaders closed the doors of the polling booth and did not allow voters or YSRC agents to enter. Police stepped in to open the door after YSRC protested, said YSRC leaders. Police had made elaborate security arrangements in the seven mandals of the Polavaram Project as the Maoists had called for poll boycott. In tribal areas of Gopalapuram, Polavaram and Rampachodavaram constituencies, the EC provided transportation for voters to reach the nearest polling station. Special vehicles were provided for the transport of the disabled and the aged in several assembly constituencies across the two Godavari districts.

title: AP assembly elections: Two local leaders of TDP and YSRCP dead in poll clashes
og_title: AP assembly elections: Two local leaders of TDP and YSRCP dead in poll clashes
content: TIRUPATI: A Telugu Desam Party (TDP) local leader Sidda Bhaskar Reddy and Pulla Reddy of YSRCP died after clashes broke out between TDP and YSRCP cadres at Meerapuram of Anantapur district. An altercation broke out between the TDP and YSRC activists over Sidda Bhaskar Reddy functioning as a dummy agent for the TDP. YSRC activists led by local leader Pulla Reddy alleged that the followers of JC Diwakar Reddy were resorting to rigging and demanded the TDP activists to refrain from the undemocratic act. Within minutes the two groups clashed with one another with sticks and hunting sickles. Stones were also pelted on one another even as the cops tried to bring the situation under control but in vain. Several activists, including local TDP leader Sidda Bhaskar Reddy and Pulla Reddy of YSRCP, sustained grievous injuries. They were immediately rushed to a local hospital, where Sidda Bhaskar Reddy and Pulla Reddy were declared as brought dead by the doctors. Meanwhile, tension prevailed in Raptadu assembly in Anantapur district where Telugu Desam party activists and the cadres of the YSRC clashed with one another leaving several activists injured. Trouble broke out after one Kanthaiah, alleged to be a YSRC sympathizer destroyed an EVM at a polling station in Sanapa in Atmakur mandal. The local cops arrested three persons in connection with the incident. Though Minister Paritala Sunitha, who is monitoring the poll proceedings for her son Paritala Sriram, who is in the poll fray on behalf of the TDP in Raptadu assembly, rushed to Sanapa village, she was obstructed and denied entry into the village by YSRC activists. When TDP cadres tried to move-in forcefully, both the groups attacked each other with sticks and also pelted stones. Several activists injured in the clash were rushed to local hospitals. Sunitha alleged YSCR activists laid seize to 40-odd villages, including Thopudurthi, and were denying entry to the Telugu Desam party sympathizers arriving to vote. Though we took the issue to the notice of the district collector, SP and the Anantapur DIG, no action was taken to ensure free and fair polls even as the YSRC is instigating violence, she lamented. Paritala Sunitha demanded a re-poll in Sanapa and other polling booths where EVMs were delayed for various reasons in the Rapthadu assembly. In another incident of violence, an EVM was destroyed by Guntakal Jana sena candidate Madhusudhan Gupta at a polling station in Gooty.

title: 2 killed in violence across districts
og_title: 2 killed in violence across districts
content: BEHRAMPORE/CANNING: From Murshidabad’s Behrampore to Canning on the city’s fringe, factionalism between Trinamool’s parent unit and youth wing allegedly claimed lives of two partymen between Sunday evening and Monday morning. Though Trinamool leaders blamed the opposition — BJP in Canning and Congress in Behrampore — for the killings, kin of the dead alleged that intra-party factionalism led to the deaths. Canning victim Kartik Naskar’s wife Shabnam is, in fact, a Trinamool pradhan of a local gram panchayat . Kartik was gunned down, allegedly by Trinamool Youth Congressmen who stopped his bike while he was returning home to Canning’s Dariya on Sunday night. Alleging that a local TMC leader was her husband’s killer, Shabnam rejected local Trinamool Youth Congress leader Soukat Mollah’s claim that Kartik was a victim of a personal feud over a plot of land. Soukat, however, admitted that the person behind the killing was, indeed, a Trinamool Youth Congress leader but was driven by personal enmity. At Niallishpara, victim Nazmul Sheikh (33) was shot dead at point blank range, allegedly by two bike-borne masked men, on Monday morning.

title: Complaint filed after man thrashes wife and son
og_title: Complaint filed after man thrashes wife and son
content: AHMEDABAD: A 41-year-old woman from Khadia, who was allegedly being beaten every now and then by her husband over trivial issues, on Sunday filed a complaint of domestic violence against him when he thrashed their 10-year-old son on Friday. Complainant stated before the Khadia police that she got married 11years ago with an advocate, who practices at the Metropolitan court in Gheekanta. She stated that her husband tortured her from past eight years over trivial issues. “On Friday, when I was doing some household chores in the kitchen, I heard my son crying loudly. When I went to his room, I saw my husband verbally abusing him and my son was crying. On being asked, my son told me that he asked my husband not to talk loudly when he was studying. This did not go well with my husband and he thrashed him. When I asked my husband on why he had beaten the child, he even thrashed me badly,” said the complainant.

title: Three more held for violence in Tilamol
og_title: Three more held for violence in Tilamol
content: QUEPEM: Three more persons have been arrested by police in connection with allegations of assault and other crimes in Tilamol and Xeldem, as peace returned to the area after tension prevailed from afternoon till late night on Sunday. The arrest on Monday took the tally to seven, deputy superintendent of police, Uttam Raut Dessai told TOI. Four had been arrested late Sunday night for allegedly molesting a woman, assaulting other residents and pushing a constable into the drain. A few residents were injured after the Curchorem residents attacked them with knives and hockey sticks. The residents of Tilamoll and Xeldem had blocked the national highway demanding the immediate arrest of the culprits on Sunday, the situation is under control at Tilamoll. Dessai said the three main accused Gitesh Naik, Swapnil Naik and Guptesh Naik are still absconding and police teams have been deployed to nab them. Quepem police on Monday produced all seven accused before judicial magistrate first class court at Quepem for two days police custody.

title: Arunachal govt orders judicial probe into PRC violence
og_title: Arunachal govt orders judicial probe into PRC violence
content: ITANAGAR: The BJP government in Arunachal Pradesh has announced a judicial probe into the large scale rioting, violence and vandalism during the recent PRC protest that left three people dead.
